descriptions.short_description: The puzzle which started it all!
descriptions.full_description: The Rubiks Cube is the first really popular Twisty Puzzle ever, but not the first one to be created. In fact, it was lagging behind an early 2x2x2 almost 11 years.

descriptions.short_description: The First Mass Produced Flat-Faced Proportional Master Pyraminx
descriptions.full_description: Previously there were only hand-made prototypes or unproportional, rounded exemplars of this puzzle.

descriptions.short_description: Being part of MF8s dodecahedron-series, this puzzle was the first edge-turning dodecahedral puzzle.
descriptions.full_description: The first sample was designed by Clayton Ertley, MF8 mass-produced this puzzle in 2011. Like all 'Helicopter'-type puzzles it can jumble, but this was the first of them that showed the hidden center pieces.

descriptions.short_description: This puzzle is part of MF8s dodecahedron-series, its original name was 'Starminx 1'.
descriptions.full_description: Invented by Aleh Hladzilin in 2009, this puzzle got mass-produced by MF8. It is one of 3 different puzzles which all have the same face-pattern, which is why this has an added 1 in the name for distinction. It is a deeper cut Pyraminx-Crystal.

descriptions.short_description: The second puzzle out of 3 all with the same face-pattern, this one being Edge Turning
descriptions.full_description: This puzzle was not only the first edge-turning dodecahedron ever, but also included 2 types of jumbling - great news, because it was released shortly before christmas by DrewSeph. It had to be made quite big to be stable. It is one of 3 different puzzles which all have the same face-pattern, which is why this has an added 2 in the name for distinction.

descriptions.short_description: The third installment of deeper cut dodecahedrons by Andrew Cormier, this time Corner Turning and way deeper cut
descriptions.full_description: This puzzle, also presented by DrewSeph, is way deeper cut than the other Starminxes. There are 132 visible and 311 internal pieces inside. It is one of 3 different puzzles which all have the same face-pattern, which is why this has an added 3 in the name for distinction.

descriptions.short_description: A Starminx with curvy cuts and additional Corner pieces
descriptions.full_description: This puzzle is a variation of the Starminx 1, where the cuts were made curvy. This results in a smaller star on the face, but additional Corner Pieces with orientation. This puzzle is part of MF8s dodecahedron-series.

descriptions.short_description: The most shallow cut and non-trivial Corner-turning dodecahedron.
descriptions.full_description: Invented in 2009 by Luke Harry and first created by Kevin Uhrik the same year, this puzzle is the equivalent of the Dino Cube on a dodecahedron. It was mass-produced by MF8 in 2011 under the misleading name 'Starminx', because it had the same face-pattern as the other 3. It is also part of MF8s dodecahedron-series.

descriptions.short_description: Also known as 'Rex Dodecahedron', which was the name given by its inventor
descriptions.full_description: Mechanically this puzzle is equivalent to a Face turning icosahedron. It was invented by Mr. Fok and is the second Corner turning dodecahedron ever made. Because the kites are symmetrical this puzzle can also jumble. Another puzzle from the MF8s dodecahedron-series.

descriptions.short_description: The deep cut Face-turning dodecahedron, also Void
descriptions.full_description: It was first created by Jason Smith in early 2008 (seen in the 3rd picture), but unlike this version it used a knucklehead mechanism. Just like the Master Pentultimate by MF8, this puzzle is simultaniously a Void Pentultimate, because its mechanism is based on rails. In fact, the mechanism is identical, only the outer pieces are larger. This puzzle is part of MF8s dodecahedron-series.

descriptions.short_description: The Master Version of the Pentultimate
descriptions.full_description: The first puzzle out of MF8s dodecahedron-series to have a rails-mechanism. The center-pieces are just caps, meaning this is the Void version at the same time.

descriptions.short_description: Edge-turning, jumbling puzzle, Part of Dayans Gem series
descriptions.full_description: The shape of this puzzle is based on a truncated octahedron. It can jumble because its edge-turning, similarly to the Helicopter Cube, which geometry its based on. Also available stickerless, although unusually the inner pieces don't add to the solving challenge

descriptions.short_description: Jumbling puzzle with 2 different types of turns, Part of Dayans Gem series
descriptions.full_description: The sides of this puzzle are made up of squares and truncated triangles, which creates a non-platonic shape which can be reached by extending the hexagonal sides of the Dayan Gem 1. It is edge- and face-turning, and also jumbles on its edge-turns.

descriptions.short_description: Non-jumbling puzzle with 2 types of turns, same shape as Gem 1, Part of Dayans Gem series
descriptions.full_description: Although this puzzle has the same shape as the Gem 1 from the same series, it is very different due to beeing a hybrid and face-turning. Designed by Scott Bedard under the name of 'Concept-11' it has the exact same face-pattern like the Gem 4.

descriptions.short_description: Non-jumbling, deep-cut hybrid puzzle based on a 4 layer face-turning Octahedron, Part of Dayans Gem series
descriptions.full_description: Looks exactly like the Dayan Gem 3, but it only has one type of move. This puzzle has the same face-turning hexagons, but instead of the turning squares its also deep-cut.

descriptions.short_description: Shape-mod of the F-Skewb, Part of Dayans Gem series
descriptions.full_description: Based on a lower order Master Skewb, this puzzle doesn't jumble nor shapeshift. The stickerless version makes the solve harder because internal pieces have color too.

descriptions.short_description: Variant of the Wheel of Wisdom, looks like a combination of the Pyraminx Crystal and a football, Part of Dayans Gem series
descriptions.full_description: Invented by Daqing Bao, this 30 sided puzzle with 6 octahedrons and 24 pentagonal faces looks insanely complicated. If the Dayan Wheel of Wisdom would be a Megaminx, this would be the Pyraminx Crystal.

descriptions.short_description: The principle of a Cross Cube brought to a Curvy Copter, Part of Dayans Gem series
descriptions.full_description: Although they might look like it, the hexagonal faces aren't regular hexagons. The hexagon-turns are equivalent to Curvy Copter-turns, and the square sides represent the Cross section of this puzzle.

descriptions.short_description: Also called the Master Tetraminx, Part of Dayans Gem series
descriptions.full_description: Works similar to a Professor Pyraminx, but the cut-depth is different which results in different pieces. Like most other Dayan Gems it was invented by Daqing Bao.

descriptions.short_description: Offset and midturn-reshape of a 3x3x3 Rubiks Cube, solved by shape
descriptions.full_description: First created by Virust Cube, this puzzle had a high demand from the beginning, giving a unique look and solving experience, which resulted in it being mass-produced. The mechanism is just a normal Rubiks cube.

descriptions.short_description: The predecessor of the Ghost Cube, first created by Tony Fisher
descriptions.full_description: The first prototype was already created in 1999 by Tony Fisher. Technically it is a Ghost Skewb, but was created way before other Ghost-type puzzles. Every piece is uniquely shaped, so the puzzle is solved by shape.

descriptions.short_description: Again another shape transformation of a cube by Tony Fisher
descriptions.full_description: This puzzle was already prototyped in 1991 by Tony Fisher, but not released until 2008. Just like the Ghost Cube its mechanism is a normal Rubiks Cube. The solving is different though, because the centers have an orientation. Today there are also more rounded versions available, and Traiphum has made variants up to a 9x9x9 version.

descriptions.short_description: The 2x2x2 cube by notorious Knock-Off-company ShengShou
descriptions.full_description: Up to 6x6 all ShengShou cubes are very similar to the V-Cube ones, which is why they are referred to as 'Knock-Offs'.

descriptions.short_description: The 3x3x3 cube by notorious Knock-Off-company ShengShou
descriptions.full_description: Up to 6x6 all ShengShou cubes are very similar to the V-Cube ones, which is why they are referred to as 'Knock-Offs'.

descriptions.short_description: The 4x4x4 cube by notorious Knock-Off-company ShengShou
descriptions.full_description: Up to 6x6 all ShengShou cubes are very similar to the V-Cube ones, which is why they are referred to as 'Knock-Offs'.

descriptions.short_description: The 5x5x5 cube by notorious Knock-Off-company ShengShou
descriptions.full_description: Up to 6x6 all ShengShou cubes are very similar to the V-Cube ones, which is why they are referred to as 'Knock-Offs'.

descriptions.short_description: The 6x6x6 cube by notorious Knock-Off-company ShengShou
descriptions.full_description: Up to 6x6 all ShengShou cubes are very similar to the V-Cube ones, which is why they are referred to as 'Knock-Offs'.

descriptions.short_description: The 7x7x7 cube by ShengShou
descriptions.full_description: The first mass-produced cubic 7x7x7, but V-Cube claims they invented the mechanism first.

descriptions.short_description: The 8x8x8 cube by ShengShou
descriptions.full_description: The first mass-produced cubic 8x8x8, but V-Cube claims they invented the mechanism first.

descriptions.short_description: The 9x9x9 cube by ShengShou
descriptions.full_description: The first mass-produced cubic 9x9x9, but V-Cube claims they invented the mechanism first.

descriptions.short_description: The 10x10x10 cube by ShengShou
descriptions.full_description: The first mass-produced cubic 10x10x10, but V-Cube claims they invented the mechanism first.

descriptions.short_description: The 11x11x11 cube by ShengShou
descriptions.full_description: The first mass-produced cubic 11x11x11, but V-Cube claims they invented the mechanism first.

descriptions.short_description: Currently the largest mass-produced rubiks-like twisty puzzle available to buy
descriptions.full_description: Often described like 'Just as smooth like their 7x7', MoYu really surprised the Twisty Puzzling community when releasing this puzzle. Never before seen stability and the impressive look made this puzzle despite its high price tag a best-seller.

descriptions.short_description: The dodecahedral equivalent of a 2x2x2 Cube
descriptions.full_description: Based on the mechanism of a Megaminx, this puzzle hides all the central edges and center pieces, resulting in the possibility of parity.

descriptions.short_description: The dodecahedral equivalent of a 3x3x3 Cube
descriptions.full_description: This puzzle has the same type of pieces like a 3x3x3, and even the inner cuts are designed in the same way as a Rubiks Cube, only spherical.

descriptions.short_description: The dodecahedral equivalent of a 4x4x4 Cube
descriptions.full_description: Based on the mechanism of a Gigaminx, this puzzle hides all the central edges and center pieces, resulting in the possibility of parity.

descriptions.short_description: The dodecahedral equivalent of a 5x5x5 Cube
descriptions.full_description: This puzzle has the same type of pieces like a 5x5x5, and even the inner cuts are designed in the same way as in that cube, only spherical.

descriptions.short_description: The dodecahedral equivalent of a 6x6x6 Cube
descriptions.full_description: Based on the mechanism of a Teraminx, this puzzle hides all the central edges and center pieces, resulting in the possibility of parity.

descriptions.short_description: The dodecahedral equivalent of a 7x7x7 Cube
descriptions.full_description: This puzzle has the same type of pieces like a 7x7x7, and even the inner cuts are designed in the same way as in that cube, only spherical.

descriptions.short_description: Being part of VeryPuzzles Clover series, this puzzle has 2 axis per edge, resulting in a unique look and jumbling experience
descriptions.full_description: It can be seen as a higher order Curvy Copter, but instead of 1 axis per edge this has 2, but next to each other. This creates never before seen pieces, a jumbling only puzzle and quite a mess when scrambled.

descriptions.short_description: Being part of VeryPuzzles Clover series, this puzzle has 2 axis per edge, resulting in a unique look and jumbling experience
descriptions.full_description: Being familiar to the Clover Cube, this puzzle has 2 axis next to each other per edge. This creates never before seen pieces, a jumbling only puzzle and quite a mess when scrambled.

descriptions.short_description: Being part of VeryPuzzles Clover series, this puzzle has 2 axis per edge, resulting in a unique look and jumbling experience
descriptions.full_description: Being familiar to the Clover Cube, this puzzle has 2 axis next to each other per edge. This creates never before seen pieces, a jumbling only puzzle and quite a mess when scrambled. There also exists a fragmentation-variant of this puzzle, unbandaging some of the jumbling (seen in the last picture).

descriptions.short_description: Being part of VeryPuzzles Clover series, this puzzle has 2 axis per edge, resulting in a unique look and jumbling experience
descriptions.full_description: Being familiar to the Clover Cube, this puzzle has 2 axis next to each other per edge. This creates never before seen pieces, a jumbling only puzzle and quite a mess when scrambled. Additionally there are non-jumbling turns possible on the corners.

descriptions.short_description: A deeper cut Dino-Cube with centers and wings
descriptions.full_description: This puzzle can be described as a deeper cut Dino Cube, as well as a Master Skewb without its Corners. Because the cuts are curvy, a set of pieces is created which couldnt exist with plain cuts.

descriptions.short_description: A Rex Cube with visible corners, or the Master version of a Skewb
descriptions.full_description: A patent for this puzzle was already filed in the 1980s by Aleksandr Ordynets, but he had no working prototype. The first working prototype was only created over 20 years later by Katsuhiko Okamoto in 2003, and mass-produced by LanLan in 2010. Normally a Master Skewb would be based mechanically on a Skewb, but this Master Skewb is based on the mechanism of a Rex Cube with added Corners.

descriptions.short_description: A helicopter Cube with Curvy Cuts, which makes the hidden center pieces visible
descriptions.full_description: Developed by Ton van der Zanden, this puzzle is considered a 'Must-Have' for many Cubers because of its smooth turning, unique solving experience and beautiful appearance.
